posts.cooked: After the first day of the qualification, i saw numerous robots with different elevator design. There are cascading and continuous, both of them accomplishing their task pretty well. I was just wondering what are the advantages and disadvantages of these systems, and where to used these design?

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Cascades are COTS so they are easier to get and make. I think a big advantage to continuous is the fact that the weight isn’t multiplied with each extra stage so I think it’s faster but Im not fully sure.

posts.name: Brandon King
posts.cooked: Continuous elevators make that cool “click click click” sound, but cascading elevators don’t.

posts.name: John Fogarty
posts.cooked: Not sure what you mean about when you say one is COTS because the rigging can be done either way with most COTS elevators with the parts they come with

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: I don’t know of any full COTS elevators (as opposed to non-powertrain bearing block sets) that are continuous. TTB and GreyT don’t have an out-of-the-box continuous option, but come with all of the parts for cascade.

posts.name: Matt Golman
posts.cooked:
I usually default to continuous, it requires less reduction from the motor (and less load on the rope/chain), keeps the CG lower through the range of motion, and moves less mass through the first half of the lift.

Use cascade if you care about the position of the intermediate stages (2018 climbs, tricky pass-through mechanisms, etc) or if you really need to counterbalance the elevator with a CF spring.

They will both do the general job of lifting stuff, and it’s rare that one or the other is truly the “wrong” choice.

posts.name: Peyton Yeung
posts.cooked: For lower load applications (or FTC ) the Compact Linear Slide is a continuously rigged lift. It was done this way to reduce complexity on stringing and make it easier for motor selection (cascade typically requires higher gear ratios).

link_counts.title: Robits Compact Linear Slide - AndyMark, Inc

posts.cooked:
Continuous almost always imo. Its generally easier, has less parts, is marginally lighter due to less gearing needed, is marginally faster due to lifting less weight at the start, and only requires a single tension point resulting in much less maintainence.

Cascade mostly only makes sense if you want the N:1 reduction on the 1st stage compared to the carriage, which isn’t the case this year. CF springs are largely unnessesary when you can shove a bunch of 400W motors on your mechanism and are more of a hassle than the very small fractions of a second they save (because inertia matters a lot more).

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
That’s fair.  I should have qualified it with, “full COTS elevators approximately of the size to play games like Power Up, Deep Space, Charged Up, or Reefscape.”

Unless I’ve missed something, there isn’t a COTS solution with rigging that would be the right size to do this.  Again, as CuteRedpandas says, this makes them more accessible.

Alex_Y:

Cascade mostly only makes sense if

…or if you’re building your first elevator ever and want to give yourselves the best chance of it working, so you get The Thrifty Elevator or the GreyT Elevator kit.  More-efficient 'bot is only better than less-efficient 'bot if you can actually build the former and get it to work.
